note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2196-2-21**]     Discharge Date:  [**2196-2-23**]

Date of Birth:   [**2168-5-16**]     Sex:  M

Service:  TRAUMA

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 27-year-old
male who was brought to the [**Hospital1 **] Emergency
Department following a motor vehicle accident when his car
hit a pole.  The patient got out of the car after the initial
event and was then struck by another car.  On arrival, there
was a questionable seat belt sign versus dark ecchymosis.
The patient was apparently combative and required intubation
in order to control him.  The patient was then transferred to
the Trauma Surgical Intensive Care Unit after initial
stabilization.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  None.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  None.

VITALS ON ARRIVAL:  Blood pressure 120/palp.  Pulse of 70.
Temperature of 98.6.  Physical examination:  Head, eyes,
ears, nose and throat:  Pupils equal, round and reactive to
light.  Extraocular movements intact.  Cervical spine:  No
tenderness.  Chest:  Bilateral breath sounds, clear to
auscultation.  Abdomen:  Soft, nontender, nondistended
abdomen.  Pelvis:  Stable.  Rectal:  Normal tone, guaiac
negative.  Extremities:  Right knee abrasion. No deformities.
Pulse:  2+.  Neurological:  Combative.  Back/spine:  No
deformities or step-offs.  GCS initial time was 14.

RADIOGRAPHIC RESULTS:  Initial assessment:  Chest x-ray was
negative.  Pelvis x-ray was negative.  C spine was negative.
CT of the head negative.  TLS spine were negative.  Knee was
negative.  CT abdomen and pelvis negative.  Initial CBC:
White blood cell count was 4.8 and hematocrit was 35.  The
patient had a positive blood alcohol level of 270 as well.
Also, the patient had a laceration of the scalp which was
stapled.

CONCISE SUMMARY OF HOSPITAL COURSE:   After the patient spent
the initial evening in the Intensive Care Unit secondary to
intubation, the patient was extubated the following morning
and transferred to the floor for further evaluation.  The
patient's stay on the floor was completely uneventful.  The
patient was evaluated with Physical Therapy who felt he was
safe to go home.  The patient ultimately left with
instructions for follow-up in the Trauma Clinic for removal
of staples and re-evaluation of his condition.

CONDITION OF DISCHARGE:  Good.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  To home.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Head laceration.
2.  Multiple body contusions.
3.  Status post motor vehicle accident.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Ibuprofen 800 mg three times a day for pain.
2.  Percocet 1-2 tablets every 4-6 hours for pain.

FOLLOW-UP PLANS:  The patient has been instructed to make an
appointment for follow-up in the Trauma Clinic.






                          [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 520**], M.D.  [**MD Number(1) 521**]
